newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa's Sorghum Breweries head quits - paper.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa's Sorghum Breweries head quits - paper.

text.p: The chief executive of South Africa's National Sorghum Breweries (NSB) Mohale Mahanyele has resigned, Business Report newspaper reported on Thursday.

It said Mahanyele, who was also chairman of the board, resigned with immediate effect on Wednesday, making way for a new management team appointed by United Breweries of India, which holds a 30 percent stake in the loss-making brewer.
United Breweries paid 70 million rand in 1995 for its stake in the firm which brews beer and sorghum beer and also has a contract to manage NSB operations.

"The board agreed that the United Breweries management team should be allowed to pursue the management of the company, necessary for its recovery and prosperity," said Vijay Mallya, chairman of United Breweries and executive vice-chairman of NSB.
Mahanyele remains a direct and indirect owner of 6.6 million shares or about 10 percent of NSB equity. He will also be paid an undisclosed amount as part of a three-year restraint of trade deal.
NSB was also reported to be seeking a black investor group to take a share.
